column4: Yeah, exactly. It is actually a remote web server that has to be able to do printouts on the printers on the local network
I've done "remote" printing before, but it was a network printer and I used ssh port-forwarding
that is almost the exact setup I use (ssl my_server_ip -Lprinter_port:printer_ip:printer_port) then add the "localhost" printer in cups :)
Hmm, I am trying to test port forwarding locally (by tunneling via localhost), but when I try to use lpr, it says "Connection refused"
what port did you forward (just copy-paste your ssh command)
The SSH tunnel connection says: "open failed: Connection refused"
ssh -L 8324:localhost:689 daniel@localhost
Sorry, it should be port 631
you don't want to ssh into localhost, you want to ssh into the server that has access to the printers!
Yeah, I know that, but currently I do not have that server. I just wanted to test that tunneling worked, and that cups did not complain
I managed to get it to work. I had written the wrong port number for CUPS
you can't forward to a port that is in use (try forwarding 631 to 632 to see if it's working)
is the printer a network printer, or connected directly to the other machine?
All printers will be network printers, all connected to one workstation that has an internet connection
However, tunneling actually seems to work. Thanks a lot!
do you need access to *all* printers, or just one?
if you need to access a *lot* of internal resources, you may want to consider a VPN, it's more involved to set up, but may save some work in the future
I need access to them all. I'll discuss a VPN with my boss.
you can also port-forward directly to the printers, then you are accessing cups localy (may be more or less troublesome)
just make sure you firewall the external machine, you don't want the entire internet being able to use those forwarded ports!
Nah, I rather just port forward to one printer server. Then I just need to know the printer names in order to print with lpr.
A firewall will be used of course :)
